content: Just a note, I ran into the same issue I had with this new Ubercart install as I did on the last Ubercart install - where quantity does not appear in cart. (Checking the boxes in product settings (Display an optional quantity field in 'Add to Cart) does not save - perhaps default this to 'true' as a permanent fix?). The same fix works. Has anyone used Ubercart in Backdrop for a store selling products with attributes/options and stock levels?
To me it seems that attributes/options and stock levels aren't compatible OOTB...

@BWPanda, not yet in Backdrop, but we sell T-shirts at https://origamiusa.org/catalog (D7), using attributes/options for the shirt sizes. Each option has its own stock number, so the different shirt sizes are tracked individually in stock. We'll be migrating this store to Backdrop sometime in the next year (hence my recent contributions to uc_stock, uc_price_per_role, etc.). The intention is to have attributes/options/stock working the same in Backdrop as currently in D7.
Yeah, from what I've seen so far in Backdrop, options don't have their own stock currently...
I'm basically wondering if I need this Drupal module ported over, for example: https://www.drupal.org/project/ubercart_attribute_stock
Ugh! https://www.drupal.org/project/uc_option_image doesn't exist for Backdrop yet. This is where I'm really starting to miss Drupal Commerce...

I don't know if you need that module, but I can affirm that the current Backdrop version of Ubercart does support stock tracking for individual options. I haven't yet ported all the modules needed for our store's move, but after upgrading it from D7 to the current version of UC on BD (1.x-3.13.0-rc2), I can confirm that the stock levels on individual T-shirt sizes came over in the upgrade, and if I administratively create an order that contains one of the tracked options, the stock is properly decremented on that option's SKU.

Been thinking... What are some general thoughts on creating a hybrid of commerce and Ubercart?

Ubercart is old and clunky but easy to use and commerce is an absolute PITA to work with all the way around. I've wished there was a better e-commerce experience that took some of the newer takeaways from commerce and implemented them into the simplicity of Ubercart.

Personally, I hate commerce. It was never designed for end users or site builders (despite what anyone says).

I use Ubercart on a regular basis and I think my biggest complaint is how the options/attributes work. It needs updated.

Point is, if anyone is interested in this, I would love to be involved.

I'm working on a freebie commerce site ATM, and I tried Ubercart but it was too hard, not enough modules ported, etc. So I looked around and found Foxy.io. I've decided to use it instead. As a result, I'm now building the products, attributes, options, etc. all in Backdrop (using Paragraphs for the attributes/options), and I'm loving that so much more. More freedom to decide how the structure works, etc. Point being that if we can leave as much stuff to core Backdrop as possible (i.e. content types, views, etc.) then just add on the commerce stuff, I think that's the best way forward.

Foxy.io | Flexible Ecommerce for Your Website
Foxy’s hosted cart & payment page allow you to sell anything, using your existing website or platform.

I had a look at Foxy some time ago, also at their competitor Snipcart (which is much more expensive). Good to hear that you have good experiences with Foxy, I still have to decide how to move on with my current D7 commerce clients. Basically, I also see the benefit to separate the checkout process.

Ha, yeah I've literally been researching the differences between Foxy and SnipCart yesterday and today. For this site, there's not going to more than 100 orders/month or more than $700 in monthly revenue, so the monthly cost of the two is very similar. In the end I chose Foxy because their HTML code is based around <form> elements with hidden fields for the various values, compared with SnipCart's <button> element with attributes for the values. IMO a form element seems to make more sense. But I could have easily gone with SnipCart too. Both look good.
:-) But Snipcart has a 2% or similar fee on every purchase, don't they? My customers simply won't accept this. Foxy has some cents per order, not a % charge, or has this changed in the meantime?
Did you also have a look at this one? https://www.drupal.org/project/foxycart

Foxy: $15/month + 0.5% transaction fee (min 1c, max 15c, no fee for first 100 transactions/month)
SnipCart: 2% transaction fee (unless you make <$677/month, then it's $14/month fee)
So for my site, Foxy is $15/mth and SnipCart is $14/mth

That module deals with the attribute/option core UC module. It will allow different images per option. What I managed to do was create a completely different node page load based on the drop-down.

Options are confined to the respective node whereas my variations change the physical node itself.

Having variations on individual pages allows for "each product is a line item" which solves two problems: 1) Better SEO 2) Better identification for accounting software that requires every product to be a product.

Having each product as its own line item for accounting purposes is precisely why Commerce went the route of "every product is a product" and they did away with options/attributes. It's the "standard" way of doing e-commerce however not every store needs this and it is way more complicated to maintain and setup than the UC attribute system.

I personally like using attributes as a way to test a product. I can setup one page with attributes and test to see if I get any traction. If no, I don't waste a bunch of time. If yes, that tells me it's worth breaking each product out into its own node variant.

The one problem with commerce OOTB is that they didn't create a "bundled line item". This means it isn't possible to have multiple line items housed within a single line item. There was somebody working on a contrib for this around the time I stopped focusing on commerce so I don't know it's status. Bundling line items would allow a store to offer "made to order" products where you customize a product based on individual components.

Imagine wanting to sell a computer. You can sell each component separately so they need to be their own line item, but if you add those to a custom built computer, that computer needs a line item that houses the components. The way commerce is designed, the store owner has no idea if the components go inside the computer or if they are being purchased as individual components.

Any Ubercart users out there, I'm interested in feedback on this issue:
https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/ubercart/issues/251

The question is whether uninstalling Ubercart should completely remove the product content type (and related nodes). Drupal 7 does not do this on uninstall, but it does make sense to do it in terms of clean-up given that Ubercart creates that content type upon installation. Obviously the danger is that someone uninstalls Ubercart and loses content that they may not have realized was about to be deleted.

https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/ubercart/issues/251

Remove content types and nodes on uninstall? · Issue #251 · backdrop-contrib/ubercart
When module uc_product_kit is uninstalled, should the product_kit content type and and any nodes be removed during hook_uninstall()? Ditto for module uc_product and any of its product nodes? Looks ...
Hum... Yes if a sandbox, no if live site.
